information sheet.csv: Title of Study: Investigating The Effect of Flavonoid Consumption on Cognition and Mood in Young People
Title of Study: Investigating The Effect of Flavonoid Consumption on Cognition and Mood in Young People

We would be grateful to you if you could assist us by participating in our online study exploring whether a diet rich in flavonoids is associated with mood and cognitive task performance. Flavonoids are naturally-occurring compounds found in foods such as berry & citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, tea, chocolate and red wine. Previous research has shown that consumption of flavonoid-rich foods may improve cognition and mood.

The study will be completed online via a weblink and will not require any changes in diet. Your participation will be done in one sitting from any location where you have access to the internet. It is advised that you complete the study on a laptop, desktop or tablet device for best screen presentation. The study will take approximately 30 minutes, during which time you will complete a cognitive task and a set of questionnaires asking general information about you and asking questions about your mood and diet.

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. All information will be destroyed after a period of 5 years from the completion of the project. Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you score above threshold for risk of depression you will be notified via email. Upon completion of the study all participants will be provided with mood & depression support links.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct. If you have any questions or concerns then please get in contact with the study supervisor Dr Katie Barfoot through this email katie.barfoot@reading.ac.uk Thank you for your help.

consent_form.csv: Please select 'Yes' after each statement to confirm it has been read and agreed to.

I have read and had explained to me by Hannah-Rose Human, Lyana Halawi or Tatiana Tavares the accompanying Information Sheet relating to the project on: the effect of flavonoid consumption on cognition and mood in young people

I have had explained to me the purposes of the project and what will be required of me, and any questions I have had have been answered to my satisfaction. I agree to the arrangements described in the Information Sheet in so far as they relate to my participation.
I have had explained to me what information will be collected about me, what it will be used for, who it may be shared with, how it will be kept safe, and my rights in relation to my data.
I understand that participation is entirely voluntary and that I have the right to withdraw from the project any time, and that this will be without detriment.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.

I understand that this project has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and National Research Ethics committee where relevant and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct.

debrief.csv:
Debrief Sheet

Project title: The effect of flavonoid consumption on cognition and mood in young people.
Thank you for taking part in this study, we are very grateful for your contribution.

This study aims to explore whether flavonoid intake is related to mood and cognition. Flavonoids are naturally occurring compounds found in foods such as berry and citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, dark chocolate, tea and red wine. Previous research has found that flavonoids may have a beneficial effect on cognition and mood in children and older adults, however little research has investigated these effects in healthy young adults. In the current study, participants were asked to answer questionnaires on habitual diet and mood and were also asked to complete a cognitive task.

Your data will be securely stored and kept confidential. It will be automatically anonymized and cannot be traced back to you. If you choose to withdraw (see details on how to do this below), your data will not be used but will be stored along with the data of the other participants.
If you have any concerns about the research, please contact the project supervisor, Dr. Katie Barfoot.

If you choose to withdraw, if you would like further information about the study or if you would like to know about the findings once the study is complete, then please contact one of the researchers, Hannah-Rose Human, Lyana Halawi or Tatiana Tavares, via email.

If taking part in this study has raised any specific concerns about your mental health then we would suggest you contact your general practitioner (GP). We have also provided some helpful links and contacts below should you wish to seek further support.

Samaritans: the Samaritans provide a 24/7 hotline for people to confidentially talk about their feelings and problems.
Email: jo@Samaritans.org , Tel: 116 123

NHS mental health helplines: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/mental-health-helplines/

Student Welfare Team: students at the University of Reading have the opportunity to contact the Student Welfare Team to support them with difficulties they might be facing. Website: http://student.reading.ac.uk/essentials/_support-and-wellbeing/support-arrangements/welfare.aspx Email: studentwelfare@reading.ac.uk

		Kitten release (2020) author: Dr. Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk)		
*/
-->
<script>
if(typeof(parent.parent.exp_json.storage) == "undefined"){
  //prepare all trials
  
  letter_array = "{{characters}}".split("");
  
  number_of_trials = {{number_of_trials}};
  
  array_repeats = Math.ceil(number_of_trials/letter_array.length);
  
  shuffled_letters = [];
  for(var i = 0; i < array_repeats; i++){
    shuffled_letters.concat(letter_array);
  }
  shuffled_letters = shuffle(shuffled_letters);
  
  
  // insert matches
  
  
  
  

  
  for(var i = 0; i < {{letter_gap}}; i++){
    letter_array.push(null);
  }
  letter_array.push(this_letter);
  response_letter = null;
} else {
  letter_array = Trial.get("letter_array");
  letter_array.push(this_letter);
  response_letter = letter_array.splice(0,1);
}


var this_letter = "{{cue}}";
var letter_array;
$("#current_letter").html(this_letter);


//solution from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2450954/how-to-randomize-shuffle-a-javascript-array
function shuffle(array) {
  var currentIndex = array.length, temporaryValue, randomIndex;

  // While there remain elements to shuffle...
  while (0 !== currentIndex) {

    // Pick a remaining element...
    randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * currentIndex);
    currentIndex -= 1;

    // And swap it with the current element.
    temporaryValue = array[currentIndex];
    array[currentIndex] = array[randomIndex];
    array[randomIndex] = temporaryValue;
  }

  return array;
}



</script>

borcsok_ethics.csv:
School of Psychology

Earley Gate,
Whiteknights
PO Box 238,
Reading
RG6 6AL,
UK
phone +44 (0)118 378 8523
fax +44 (0)118 378 6715

Title of Study: Investigating attentional biases to neutral and pleasant images: An eye-tracking study

Information & Consent Sheet

Researchers:

Supervisors: Email: Phone:
Dr Anthony Haffey Anthony.Haffey@reading.ac.uk 0118 378 8850
Dr Lily Fitzgibbon l.t.fitzgibbon@reading.ac.uk 0118 378 8850


Experimenters Email
Rebecca Borcsok r.borcsok@student.reading.ac.uk

You are being invited to take part in some research. Before you decide whether or not to participate, it is important for you to understand why the research is being conducted and what it will involve. Please read the following information carefully.

What is the purpose of the research?

We are conducting research exploring eye movements when viewing neutral or pleasant images. The purpose of the study is to determine if individual differences influence attentional behaviour. Your participation in this study will require one 30-minute session.

Who is carrying out the research?

The data are being collected by Rebecca Borcsok, under the supervision of Dr Anthony Haffey and Dr Lily Fitzgibbon, in the School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences at University of Reading. The research has been approved by the School and University ethics committees.

What happens if I agree to take part?

If you agree to take part in this research, you will be asked to take part in a task where you will view matched pairs of images, whilst your eye movements are recorded. You will also be asked to complete a video-game style task, which records your decision-making. After the two tasks, you will also be asked to complete some questionnaires, including some that ask about your alcohol and gambling behaviours. At the end of the study, you will be debriefed on the tasks you have completed and given further information on the aims of the study.

Are there any risks associated with taking part?

One risk of taking part in this study is the issue of confidentiality. To ensure that information about your personal use of alcohol or gambling behaviour is known by to as few members of the research team as possible, this information will be held by Rebecca Borcsok only, until the study is complete. You will be identified by code only during the study, so you cannot be matched with information about alcohol use or gambling. After the study is complete, all identifying information will be removed, and only subject codes (and non-identifying information) would be matched to information about your alcohol use and gambling behaviour.

What will happen to the information I provide?

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Information linking that number to your name will be stored securely and separately from the data you provide us. All identifiable information collected for the project, such as the consent form, will be destroyed after a period of 60 months from the when the completion of the project has elapsed.

An analysis of the information will form part of our report at the end of the study and may be presented to interested parties and published in scientific journals and related media. Note that all information presented in any reports or publications will be anonymous and unidentifiable.

Is participation voluntary and what if I wish to later withdraw?

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

What if I have other questions?

If you have further questions about this study, please do not hesitate to contact the student experimenter or supervisors listed above.
I confirm that I have read the information sheet for this study. I have had the opportunity to consider the information, ask questions and have had these answered satisfactorily.
I understand that all personal information will remain confidential to the Investigator and arrangements for the storage and eventual disposal of any identifiable material have been made clear to me.
I understand that participation in this study is voluntary and that I can withdraw at any time without having to give an explanation.
I am happy to proceed with my participation.

cam_info:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Title of Project: Nature of co-occurring worry in autism.

Name of Lead Investigator: Dr Indu Dubey (De Montfort University)

Invitation paragraph

You have been invited to take part in a research study. Before you decide whether to take part it is important for you to understand why the research is being done and what it will involve. Please take time to read the following information carefully and discuss it with friends and relatives if you wish to. Ask us if there is anything that is not clear or if you would like more information. Take time to decide whether you wish to take part or not. Thank you for reading this.

What is the study about?

Worry is a commonly reported difficulty in several mental health conditions. A large number of people who are diagnosed with autism also report having significant worry interfering with their day to day life. In this study we aim to explore various ways through which different events or situations may affect the experience of worry in adults with and without autism or other mental health conditions.

What does the study involve?

If you decide to participate you will be asked to complete three questionnaires. These questionnaires will have items related to your day to day preferences and behaviours. You need to give a response to all the items presented. After completing these questionnaires you will be shown a 'Choose a box' game. In this game you will see two boxes on the screen with different numbers of locks on them. You will be asked to choose either of the boxes to look at the linked images or videos. To open a box you need to click all the locks on the chosen box. There is no right or wrong way of choosing the boxes and there is no score for choosing any one box. You are free to choose any box and look at the images/videos you like. Once the game is over, you will be directed to the debrief page, that will tell you a little more about the study and would provide you the information about the researcher if you would like to know more about the project.

Why have I been chosen?

Any adult above 18 years of age can participate in the study. Due to the nature of the project we are more interested in involving adults who have received a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorders or anxiety disorders (irrespective of co-occurring conditions).

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form. If you decide to take part you are still free to withdraw at any time during the data collection without giving a reason.

I am interested in taking part, what do I do next?

Please find a quiet room with minimal distractions. Please ensure you have a good internet connection on a PC / laptop / tablet device. Please do not run the study on a mobile phone. Make sure that you have about 60 minutes time to complete the study. Once ready please follow the link to the online study.

What if I agree to take part and then change my mind?

To withdraw from the study before completing the tasks, just close the window and contact the researcher to say that you have withdrawn. If you decide to withdraw you would need to provide your participation ID to the researchers. Researcher will then delete all the data generated by that ID from their computers. Your ID will be a unique code that can be found top on the debrief form.

What are the possible disadvantages and risks of taking part?

The participation in this study can be tiring as it may take up to 1 hour of responding to various questions and game on computer. Therefore, it is suggested that you take part only when you are feeling ready to spend one hour on the computer. Also, for some people making choices, looking at randomly chosen video clips of natural scenes or any ambiguity can be difficult to deal with. If you think you may feel distressed by these then we advise you not to participate in the study.

What are the possible benefits of taking part?

There is no direct benefit to the participants however your participation will help us understanding the nature of worry in autism. This can then help in developing suitable interventions for the same.

What if something goes wrong?

If you are harmed by taking part in this research project, there are no special compensation arrangements. If you are harmed due to someone's negligence, then you may have grounds for a legal action but you may have to pay for it. Regardless of this, if you wish to complain, or have any concerns about any aspect of the way you have been approached or treated during the course of this study, the normal University complaints mechanisms should be available to you.

Who can I complain to?

If you have a complaint regarding anything to do with this study, you can initially approach the lead investigator Dr Indu Dubey (indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk). If this achieves no satisfactory outcome, you should then contact the Administrator for the Faculty Research Ethics Committee, Research & Innovation Office, Faculty of Health & Life Sciences, 3.35 Edith Murphy House, De Montfort University, The Gateway, Leicester, LE1 9BH or hlsfro@dmu.ac.uk

Will my taking part in this study be kept confidential?

All information which is collected about you during the course of the research will be kept on a password protected database and is strictly confidential. You will be given an ID code which will be used instead of your name. Your data can be shared with the academic collaborators listed below.
Dr Mohammad Zia Ul Haq Katshu, Institute of Mental Health, Innovation Park, Triumph Road, Nottingham, NG7 2TU
Dr Anthony Haffey, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, University of Reading, Earley, Reading RG6 6BZ
Dr Christopher Retzler, Department of Psychology, University of Huddersfield, Queensgate, Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, HD1 3DH
Dr Jennifer Retzler, Department of Psychology, University of Huddersfield, Queensgate, Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, HD1 3DH

Your anonymised data will be shared with other research teams interested in further understanding it.
The raw data will be stored for up to 10 years after a study has been completed.
Members of the faculty human research ethics committee may require access to check that the study has been conducted in accordance with the approval.
You should also be aware that I may be duty bound to pass on information that you provide that reveals harm has occurred to a child or other vulnerable individual.

What will happen to the results of the research study?

The results based on performance of the group of participants will be then analysed and submitted for publication in peer reviewed scientific journals.

Who is organising and funding the research?

There is no funding source for this study. It is being run as a collaborative academic effort from Dr Indu Dubey at De Montfort University and her academic collaborators from Dr Mohammad Zia Ul Haq Katshu at the University of Nottingham, Dr Anthony Haffey at the University of Reading, Dr Christopher Retzler and Dr Jennifer Retzler at the University of Huddersfield.

Who has reviewed the study?

This study has been reviewed and approved by De Montfort University, Faculty of Health and Life Sciences Research Ethics Committee.

Contact for Further Information
Dr Indu Dubey
Lecturer in Psychology
Room 0.35, Hawthorn Building
Division of Psychology,
School of Applied Social Sciences,
De Montfort University,
Leicester, UK
Phone: 0116 366 4401
Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue

2. I understand that my participation is voluntary and that I am free to withdraw at any time without giving any reason.

3. I understand that data collected during the study may be looked at by the academic collaborators Dr Mohammad Zia Ul Haq Katshu at the University of Nottingham, Dr Anthony Haffey at the University of Reading, Dr Christopher Retzler and Dr Jennifer Retzler at the University of Huddersfield. I give permission for the research team to have access to my data.
4. I understand that my anonymized data might be shared with other researchers
5. I am over 18 years of age and I agree to take part in this study

cam_debrief:
Debrief form

Thank you so much for participating in this study. This study aims to explore how worry may affect the day to day behaviour and choices we make. Literature suggests that the worry experienced by people with autism might be different from worry experienced by other people. It is proposed that social difficulties, sensory sensitivity, or uncertainty might be the significant cause of worry for people with autism but not those without autism. In this study, we are exploring if these factors can reliably predict worry in people with autism but not in people with worry without autism. We believe this study would help shaping differential interventions for people experiencing different kinds of worry. If you would like to know more about the project, please contact the lead investigator.

If you would like to withdraw your consent, please contact the lead investigator in next 3 days. After 3 days of the participation we will not be able to delete your data.

Contact for Further Information
Dr Indu Dubey
Lecturer in Psychology
Room 0.35, Hawthorn Building
Division of Psychology,
School of Applied Social Sciences,
De Montfort University,
Leicester,
UK
Phone: 0116 366 4401
Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk

health_anxiety_inventory.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:

Each question is this section consists of a group of four statements. Please read each group of statements carefully and then select the one which best describes your feelings, over the past six months. Identify the statement by ringing the letter next to it, i.e. if you think that statement (a) is correct, ring statement (a) ; it may be that more than one statement applies, in which case, please ring any that are applicable.
I do not worry about my health.| I occasionally worry about my health. | I spend much of my time worrying about my health | I spend most of my time worrying about my health.

I notice aches/pains less than most other people (of my age). | I notice aches/pains as much as most other people (of my age). |  I notice aches/pains more than most other people (of my age).| I am aware of aches/pains in my body all the time.

As a rule I am not aware of bodily sensations or changes. | Sometimes I am aware of bodily sensations or changes. | I am often aware of bodily sensations or changes. I am constantly aware of bodily sensations or changes.

Resisting thoughts of illness is never a problem. |  Most of the time I can resist thoughts of illness. |  I try to resist thoughts of illness but am often unable to do so. |  Thoughts of illness are so strong that I no longer even try to resist them.

As a rule I am not afraid that I have a serious illness | I am sometimes afraid that I have a serious illness. | I am often afraid that I have a serious illness. | I am always afraid that I have a serious illness.

I do not have images (mental pictures) of myself being ill. | I occasionally have images of myself being ill. | I frequently have images of myself being ill. |  I constantly have images of myself being ill.

I do not have any difficulty taking my mind off thoughts about my health. | I sometimes have difficulty taking my mind off thoughts about my health. | I often have difficulty in taking my mind off thoughts about my health. | Nothing can take my mind off thoughts about my health.

I am lastingly relieved if my doctor tells me there is nothing wrong. | I am initially relieved but the worries sometimes return later. |  I am initially relieved but the worries always return later. |  I am not relieved if my doctor tells me there is nothing wrong.

If I hear about an illness I sometimes think I have it myself. |  If I hear about an illness I often think I have it myself. |  If I hear about an illness I always think I have it myself. | If I hear about an illness I never think I have it myself

If I have a bodily sensation or change I often wonder what it means. |  If I have a bodily sensation or change I always wonder what it means. |  If I have a bodily sensation or change I must know what it means. | If I have a bodily sensation or change I rarely wonder what it mean

I usually feel at fairly low risk for developing a serious illness. |  I usually feel at moderate risk for developing a serious illness. |  I usually feel at high risk for developing a serious illness. | I usually feel at very low risk for developing a serious illness
I sometimes think I have a serious illness. |  I often think I have a serious illness. | I usually think that I am seriously ill. | I never think I have a serious illness

If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I donÕt find it difficult to think about other things |  If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I sometimes find it difficult to think about other things. |  If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I often find it difficult to think about other things. |  If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I always find it difficult to think about other things.

My family/friends would say I do not worry enough about my health. | My family’friends would say I have a normal attitude to my health. |  My family’friends would say I worry too much about my health. |  My family’friends would say I am a hypochondriac

For the following questions, please think about what it might be like if you had a serious illness of a type which particularly concerns you (such as heart disease, cancer, multiple sclerosis and so on). Obviously you cannot know for definite what it would be like ; please give your best estimate of what you think might happen, basing your estimate on what you know about yourself and serious illness in general.

IfI had a serious illness I would still be able to enjoy things in my life quite a lot. |  IfI had a serious illness I would still be able to enjoy things in my life a little. |  IfI had a serious illness I would be almost completely unable to enjoy things in my life. |  IfI had a serious illness I would be completely unable to enjoy life at all.

IfI developed a serious illness there is a good chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me. |  IfI developed a serious illness there is a moderate chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me. | If I developed a serious illness there is a very small chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me. | If I developed a serious illness there is no chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me.

A serious illness would ruin some aspects of my life | A serious illness would ruin many aspects of my life. |  A serious illness would ruin almost every aspect of my life. |  A serious illness would ruin every aspect of my life.

If I had a serious illness I would not feel that I had lost my dignity | If I had a serious illness I would feel that I had lost a little of my dignity. |  If I had a serious illness I would feel that I had lost quite a lot of my dignity. |  If I had a serious illness I would feel that I had totally lost my dignity.

aq_with_stigma.csv:
Everybody has individual differences in their personality traits and ways they behave. Sometimes, people may feel they have experienced stigma, i.e. being shamed or negatively judged, for some of their traits or behaviours.

In this study we would like you to say how much you agree with a series of statements about traits/behaviours, and then how much you feel you have or have not been stigmatised for these traits/behaviours.

When you are rating the stigma, you need to take into account whether you agreed or disagreed with a statement. For example, if you agreed with a statement "I like to eat carrots", then you would need to say how shamed/stigmatised you have been for eating carrots. However, if you disagreed with the statement "I like to eat carrots" you would need to say how much you've been stigmatised for NOT eating carrots.

To help you understand this task, please answer the following question as if you never sing in the rain, and are stigmatised for not singing in the rain.
I like to sing in the rain
How strongly does this statement apply to you?
How much do you feel you have been shamed/stigmatised for this behaviour?

For the following question, imagine that you like to walk barefoot, and are stigmatised for this.



I like to walk barefoot
How strongly does this statement apply to you?
How much do you feel you have been shamed/stigmatised for this behaviour?

Now complete the following questions to reflect your own behaviour and feelings as accurately as possible.

If you don't think it makes sense to rate stigma for your behaviour, just use the "1" value on the stigma scales

information sheet.csv: Title of Study: Investigating The Effect of Flavonoid Consumption on Cognition and Mood in Young People
Title of Study: Investigating The Effect of Flavonoid Consumption on Cognition and Mood in Young People

We would be grateful to you if you could assist us by participating in our online study exploring whether a diet rich in flavonoids is associated with mood and cognitive task performance. Flavonoids are naturally-occurring compounds found in foods such as berry & citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, tea, chocolate and red wine. Previous research has shown that consumption of flavonoid-rich foods may improve cognition and mood.

The study will be completed online via a weblink and will not require any changes in diet. Your participation will be done in one sitting from any location where you have access to the internet. It is advised that you complete the study on a laptop, desktop or tablet device for best screen presentation. The study will take approximately 30 minutes, during which time you will complete a cognitive task and a set of questionnaires asking general information about you and asking questions about your mood and diet.

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. All information will be destroyed after a period of 5 years from the completion of the project. Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you score above threshold for risk of depression you will be notified via email. Upon completion of the study all participants will be provided with mood & depression support links.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct. If you have any questions or concerns then please get in contact with the study supervisor Dr Katie Barfoot through this email katie.barfoot@reading.ac.uk Thank you for your help.

debrief.csv:
Debrief Sheet

Project title: The effect of flavonoid consumption on cognition and mood in young people.
Thank you for taking part in this study, we are very grateful for your contribution.

This study aims to explore whether flavonoid intake is related to mood and cognition. Flavonoids are naturally occurring compounds found in foods such as berry and citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, dark chocolate, tea and red wine. Previous research has found that flavonoids may have a beneficial effect on cognition and mood in children and older adults, however little research has investigated these effects in healthy young adults. In the current study, participants were asked to answer questionnaires on habitual diet and mood and were also asked to complete a cognitive task.

Your data will be securely stored and kept confidential. It will be automatically anonymized and cannot be traced back to you. If you choose to withdraw (see details on how to do this below), your data will not be used but will be stored along with the data of the other participants.
If you have any concerns about the research, please contact the project supervisor, Dr. Katie Barfoot.

If you choose to withdraw, if you would like further information about the study or if you would like to know about the findings once the study is complete, then please contact one of the researchers, Hannah-Rose Human, Lyana Halawi or Tatiana Tavares, via email.

If taking part in this study has raised any specific concerns about your mental health then we would suggest you contact your general practitioner (GP). We have also provided some helpful links and contacts below should you wish to seek further support.

Samaritans: the Samaritans provide a 24/7 hotline for people to confidentially talk about their feelings and problems.
Email: jo@Samaritans.org , Tel: 116 123

NHS mental health helplines: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/mental-health-helplines/

Student Welfare Team: students at the University of Reading have the opportunity to contact the Student Welfare Team to support them with difficulties they might be facing. Website: http://student.reading.ac.uk/essentials/_support-and-wellbeing/support-arrangements/welfare.aspx Email: studentwelfare@reading.ac.uk

info_sheet.csv:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Title of Project: [[Your project title]].

Name of Lead Investigator: [[Investigator]] ([[Institute]])

Invitation paragraph

You have been invited to take part in a research study. Before you decide whether to take part it is important for you to understand why the research is being done and what it will involve. Please take time to read the following information carefully and discuss it with friends and relatives if you wish to. Ask us if there is anything that is not clear or if you would like more information. Take time to decide whether you wish to take part or not. Thank you for reading this.

What is the study about?

[[describe your experiment here]].

What does the study involve?

[[what the participant will do]]

Why have I been chosen?

[[criterion, e.g. age, etc.]]

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form. If you decide to take part you are still free to withdraw at any time during the data collection without giving a reason.

I am interested in taking part, what do I do next?

Please find a quiet room with minimal distractions. Please ensure you have a good internet connection on a PC / laptop / tablet device. [[optional: Please do not run the study on a mobile phone]]. Make sure that you have about [[time needed]] minutes time to complete the study. Once ready please follow the link to the online study.

What if I agree to take part and then change my mind?

That is fine. If you decide to withdraw you would need to provide your participation ID to the researchers. The researcher will then delete all the data generated by that ID from their computers.

What are the possible disadvantages and risks of taking part?

[[describe risks etc. here]]

What are the possible benefits of taking part?

[[benefits here]]

Who can I complain to?

If you have a complaint regarding anything to do with this study, you can initially approach the lead investigator [[lead investigator]] ([[lead_investigator_email]]). If this achieves no satisfactory outcome, you should then contact [[person to contact next]]

Will my taking part in this study be kept confidential?

All information which is collected about you during the course of the research will be kept on a password protected database and is strictly confidential. You will be given an ID code which will be used instead of your name. Your data will be shared with the following collaborators:
[[list of collaborators]]

[[optional: Your anonymised data can be shared with other research teams interested in understating it further.]]
The raw data will be stored for up to 10 years after a study has been completed.
Members of the faculty human research ethics committee may require access to check that the study has been conducted in accordance with the approval.

What will happen to the results of the research study?

The results based on performance of the group of participants will be then analysed and submitted for publication in peer reviewed scientific journals.

Who is organising and funding the research?



[[information about researchers and funders here]]

Who has reviewed the study?

This study has been reviewed and approved by [[your ethics committee]].


How is data secured?

Data is encrypted in Collector on the participant's computer. This data cannot be decrypted without the researcher's password. For more information, go to: https://some-open-solutions.github.io/collector/encryption.html

Contact for Further Information

[[your contact information]]
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue

This experiment is based on code from the OSF repository https://osf.io/jmz79/ which accompanies the publication "Online webcam-based eye tracking in cognitive science: a first look" by Semmelmann & Weigelt, published in Behavior Research Methods in 2017. Please find the abstract and information about the code, analyses, and data below. This work is intended for scientific use only. Written by Kilian Semmelmann, tolcam@ksemmelm.de, 2017.

Updates by Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk) 2020 to make this a task that works on Collector.

Webcam Setup

This study consists of multiple five-minute parts with pauses inbetween. After you clicked "start", please avoid moving your head. If you move too much, the calibration can fail and you might not be able to finish the study.

<script>
/*
* From the PEBL battery 
*/
parent.parent.card_lists = [{
    gain: {
      A: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - frequent high losses
      B: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - infrequent very high losses
      C: 50,    // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - frequent low losses
      D: 50     // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - infrequent moderate/high losses
    },
    
    /*
    * Decks A and C
    */
    // red card signifies a loss
    // black card signifies a gain
    
    /*
    * Decks B and D
    */
    // sometimes get a red card with no associated loss (red has no meaning)
    
    
    loss: {
      A: [0,0,150,0,300,0,200,0,250,350,
          0,350,0,250,200,0,300,150,0,0,
          0,300,0,350,0,200,250,150,0,0,
          350,200,250,0,0,0,150,300,0,0],
      B: [-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,1250,0, 
          -1,-1,0,1250,0,-1,-1,0,0,0,
          1250,0,-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,
          -1,1250,0,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0],
      C: [0,0,50,0,50,0,50,0,50,50, 
          0,25,75,0,0,0,25,75,0,50, 
          0,0,0,50,25,50,0,0,75,50,
          0,0,0,25,25,0,75,0,50,75],
      D: [-1,0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,0,0,250,
          -1,-1,0,0,-1,0,0,0,-1,250,
          0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,-1,0,250,0,
          0,-1,0,-1,250,-1,0,0,-1,0] 
    }
  }]
  
parent.parent.earnings = 2000
parent.parent.borrowed = 0

Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},0);
</script>

<script>
withdrawal_code = '';
var characters       = 'ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789';
var charactersLength = characters.length;
for ( var i = 0; i < 16; i++ ) {
  withdrawal_code += characters.charAt(Math.floor(Math.random() * charactersLength));
}
Trial.set("withdrawal_code",withdrawal_code);
$("#withdrawal_code").val(withdrawal_code);
Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},100);
</script>

user_trialtypes.create_feedback:
<script>

// based on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2450954/how-to-randomize-shuffle-a-javascript-array
function shuffle(array) {
  var currentIndex = array.length, temporaryValue, randomIndex;

  // While there remain elements to shuffle...
  while (0 !== currentIndex) {

    // Pick a remaining element...
    randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * currentIndex);
    currentIndex -= 1;

    // And swap it with the current element.
    temporaryValue = array[currentIndex];
    array[currentIndex] = array[randomIndex];
    array[randomIndex] = temporaryValue;
  }

  return array;
}

var growth_feedback = [{
  "correct":   "Correct: Apply that effort to the next one too",
  "incorrect": "Incorrect: You need to apply more effort to the next one"
},{
  "correct": "Correct: Your work paid off",
  "incorrect": "Incorrect: If you work harder it'll pay off"
},{
  "correct": "Correct: You must have tried hard on that one",
  "incorrect": "Incorrect: You must try harder next time"
},{
  "correct": "Correct: I can see you have put in effort to get that right",
  "incorrect": "Incorrect: You didn't put in enough effort"
},{
  "correct": "Correct: If you keep this up you'll be able to do even harder ones",
  "incorrect": "Incorrect: Keep trying and you'll get there" 
},{
  "correct": "Correct: The more you do the better you'll get",

},{

var feedback_blocks = ["fixed", "growth"];

/*
* Shuffle the above arrays
*/

shuffle(feedback_blocks);
shuffle(fixed_feedback);
shuffle(growth_feedback);
Trial.set("feedback_blocks", feedback_blocks);
Trial.set("fixed_feedback",  fixed_feedback);
Trial.set("growth_feedback", growth_feedback);

Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},100);





</script>

<script>
if(typeof(parent.parent.exp_json.storage) == "undefined"){
  //prepare all trials
  
  letter_array = "{{characters}}".split("");
  
  number_of_trials = {{number_of_trials}};
  
  array_repeats = Math.ceil(number_of_trials/letter_array.length);
  
  shuffled_letters = [];
  for(var i = 0; i < array_repeats; i++){
    shuffled_letters.concat(letter_array);
  }
  shuffled_letters = shuffle(shuffled_letters);
  
  
  // insert matches
  
  
  
  

  
  for(var i = 0; i < {{letter_gap}}; i++){
    letter_array.push(null);
  }
  letter_array.push(this_letter);
  response_letter = null;
} else {
  letter_array = Trial.get("letter_array");
  letter_array.push(this_letter);
  response_letter = letter_array.splice(0,1);
}


var this_letter = "{{cue}}";
var letter_array;
$("#current_letter").html(this_letter);


//solution from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2450954/how-to-randomize-shuffle-a-javascript-array
function shuffle(array) {
  var currentIndex = array.length, temporaryValue, randomIndex;

  // While there remain elements to shuffle...
  while (0 !== currentIndex) {

    // Pick a remaining element...
    randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * currentIndex);
    currentIndex -= 1;

    // And swap it with the current element.
    temporaryValue = array[currentIndex];
    array[currentIndex] = array[randomIndex];
    array[randomIndex] = temporaryValue;
  }

  return array;
}



</script>
